Box Plot for any metric

Source: R/create_boxplot.R
create_boxplot.Rd

Analyzes a selected metric and returns a a 'fizzy' scatter plot by default. Additional options available to return a table with distribution elements.

create_boxplot(
  data,
  metric,
  hrvar = "Organization",
  mingroup = 5,
  return = "plot"
)

Arguments

data

A Standard Person Query dataset in the form of a data frame.
metric

Character string containing the name of the metric, e.g. "Collaboration_hours"
hrvar

HR Variable by which to split metrics. Accepts a character vector, defaults to "Organization" but accepts any character vector, e.g. "LevelDesignation"
mingroup

Numeric value setting the privacy threshold / minimum group size, defaults to 5.
return

Character vector specifying what to return, defaults to "plot". Valid inputs are "plot" and "table".

Details

This is a general purpose function that powers all the functions in the package that produce box plots.

See also

Other General: create_bar_asis(), create_bar(), create_scatter(), cut_hour(), extract_hr(), hrvar_count(), identify_outlier()

Examples

## Create a fizzy plot for Work Week Span by Level Designation
create_boxplot(sq_data, metric = "Workweek_span", hrvar = "LevelDesignation", return = "plot")


## Create a summary statistics table for Work Week Span by Organization
create_boxplot(sq_data, metric = "Workweek_span", hrvar = "Organization", return = "table")

#> # A tibble: 15 x 8

## Create a fizzy plot for Collaboration Hours by Level Designation
create_boxplot(sq_data, metric = "Collaboration_hours", hrvar = "LevelDesignation", return = "plot")
